The golden ratio (symbol is the Greek letter \"phi\" shown at top) is a special number approximately equal to 1.618. It appears many times in geometry, art, architecture and other areas.
We find the golden ratio when we divide a line into two parts so that: the long part divided by the short part is also equal to the whole length divided by the long part.

This rectangle has been made using the Golden Ratio, Looks like a typical frame for a painting, doesn\'t it? Some artists and architects believe the Golden Ratio makes the most pleasing and beautiful shape.
Many buildings and artworks have the Golden Ratio in them, such as the Parthenon in Greece, but it is not really known if it was designed that way.

The Golden Ratio is equal to: 1.61803398874989484820... (etc.) The digits just keep on going, with no pattern. In fact the Golden Ratio is known to be an Irrational Number, and I will tell you more about it later.

The Golden Ratio has been said to be the most appealing ratio, and is therefore used frequently. It can be observed in nature, shells, faces, hurricanes, human bodies, animal bodies, DNA and so on. It is applied in art and architecture, making logos, music,etc..
Our own galaxy―the Milky Way is representing the Golden Ratio .
The movement of air and wind in hurricanes also follows the Fibonaccian spiral, revealing the golden ratio.
The golden ratio is seen in these flowers in terms of petal arrangement. All the petals exhibit a twisting of about 1.618034°, in order to optimize exposure to sunlight.
The same pattern is observed in the case of fractal-like fruits and vegetables. The most common examples are pineapple, red cabbage, artichokes, and Romanian cauliflower.

A DNA molecule is 34Å in length and 21Å in width. The ratio is approximately equal to the golden ratio. The same is true for the ratio of the two grooves of the helical DNA molecule, i.e., the major (21Å) and the minor (13Å) groove.

The outer calcareous shell in the case of snails, seashells, and other such examples, also exhibit the Fibonacci spiral. Snail and nautilus shells are obvious examples, where the spiral is plainly observable.
